documents.content: "Ghosts," said Dillon, sadly. "A thief!" I replied. "Why would you think it was ghosts who stole your saxophone?" "It started 30 years ago," Dillon sighed. "There were four of us, then, playing an alto sax and a baritone, plus a low 'contrabass' and a high 'soprano'." His eyes were lost in memory, and he smiled happily. "Our band had a sound like no other. We were this city's biggest saxophone quartet!" Dillon walked to a tall bookcase, which was stuffed with vinyl records, and ran a tired finger along their edges. He settled on worn-out cover, and soon the needle on his phonograph had found the record's groove. His tiny room filled with 30-year-old music, fast saxophones rollicking while a bass and a drum kept the beat. "I didn't know it then," Dillon explained, "but my saxophone also had its own legend." The quartet's producer had been a notorious music promoter named Shorty Jenkins. "Rumor had it Shorty created the careers of some famous musicians -- but then later, destroyed them!" After twenty years of working the music business, Shorty had the right connections to help acts succeed. But was he also a powerful enemy? "We did whatever Shorty said," Dillon laughed. "And we did it happily. He picked our songs, wrote our arrangements, and he even lined up the other saxophonists. Within four weeks, somehow Shorty had gotten our record into the stores." But then reading a newspaper, Dillon had spotted a disturbing article. "Shorty was bragging that he'd used the instruments of dead musicians for his new saxophone quartet. Without telling us, he'd given us each the saxophone of a famous jazz artist he'd worked with decades before. Dark whispers spread throughout the clubs. Were we exploiting the artists who came before - or preserving what made them special?" Dillon stared thoughtfully for a moment. "That Christmas, our alto saxophonist got real sick. And within two weeks, the baritone saxophonist disappeared. We couldn't continue with just two of us, but Shorty promised he'd find the group a replacement. We found out later he was stuck in a big legal fight with a trumpeter he'd discovered years before. Eventually our third saxophonist found another gig instead. And I never heard from any of them again." The vinyl record reached the end of its last song, circling through the static in its final groove until Dillon lifted the needed. "But now, even my saxophone's gone." I'd known about Dillon for years -- he was a local legend in our neighborhood, though his glory days had passed. I'd only met him recently, so I was honored that he requested my help. But I had to know one thing first. "Do you really think ghosts stole your saxophone?" "I've played it every afternoon for the last 30 years, riffing and improvising, while imagining that our band might somehow get back together. And every day, for 30 years, I've left it on that saxophone stand." He pointed to empty clasps which had always held his instrument. "Today an hour after I finished, it was gone." Could someone have broken into his apartment? "The window was closed," Dillon insisted, "and my only door was locked! I live on the second floor, high above the street." Did anyone have a key? "Well, obviously the manager of this apartment building has a key, but we never see him around. But you know who else has a key? The boy at the grocery store on the corner," Dillon said casually. "Every Friday he brings around my groceries, so I don't have to visit his store." I got his name, but also took a look at Dillon's window. It was covered with dirt, but the window lifted easily, and opened onto a fire escape. But the fire escape stopped on the second floor, its ladder to the street broken off many years before. It seemed impossible, but I asked Dillon one more question. Had he spoken to anyone before the saxophone disappeared? "That morning I gave an interview," Dillon said proudly. "A college student was recording the history of music in this neighborhood, and he'd wanted to get my story." Dillon gave me his number, and I began my investigation. The grocery store was easy to find, with its stands of fruit on the sidewalk and a busy father/son team who were putting customer orders in bags. It was the son who was Dillon's delivery boy -- a skinny teenager named Lenny. He was struggling to put six tomatoes into a sack. I asked Lenny if he delivered groceries to Dillon. "Yeah, but mostly because I feel sorry for him," he said, weighing the sack of tomatoes on a scale. "After thirty years, that man has nothing." I pointed out Dillon had a valuable antique saxophone. "A saxophone's nothing in this neighborhood," Lenny laughed. "We haven't had a club with live music here for years." As he stacked bundles of carrots into a tall pile, Lenny asked his father if just this once he could take a break, but his father sternly shouted back the family motto -- "Work all day with no breaks ever!" It seemed sad that the music scene was dying, so I was even more determined to find the legendary saxophone. I placed a phone call to a college student named Eric, who'd phoned Dillon that morning. "It's certainly a valuable saxophone," his eager voice insisted, "more valuable than most people know!" I asked him what he meant. "Those four saxophones really did come from famous jazz men," he said with excitement. "The group's producer, Shorty Jenkins had worked with the greatest musicians of the century. There are historic photographs of the quartet's saxophones that prove it. And now the instruments are ten times more valuable than they were 30 years ago, at least $30,000 apiece! Every morning while he played, Dillon had no idea how wealthy he could've been." "I began thinking about the legend after visiting a local music store called Red's," Eric continued with excitement. "Red knows the history of the neighborhood. He's the one who had given me Dillon's phone number so I could do the interview!" I wondered if Eric's visit had inadvertently tipped off a saxophone thief. Or if maybe the greedy thief could be Eric himself. Red's seemed like a likely place to investigate. He spoke in a voice that was mellow and relaxed, remembering the talented saxophone quartet and the neighborhood's glory days. "Now I give music lessons from noon to five," he laughed jovially. "But music is music!" Red remembered Eric's visit. "An excitable young kid, that's for sure," he laughed, "but he's right about Dillon's saxophones. There are collectors who'd be willing to pay a lot of money for them." Was anyone in the store during Eric's visit? "There was one customer, but he didn't buy anything. Oldest guy I've ever seen. No hair, bristly moustache, about five feet tall." Who was he? "He owns a lot of buildings in this neighborhood, but he almost never comes around." I had one last theory. Back at Dillon's place, I asked the residents about the fire escape. They all agreed that it hadn't worked in years, and couldn't even be lowered to the ground. I searched the ground below the fire escape - a patch of dirt which now contained a small flower bed. It was clear that no one had dropped here from the fire escape, or placed a ladder here to climb up. Had they asked their building manager to repair the fire escape? No one had ever seen him. He holed himself up in his fancy apartment, presumably counting all the money that they'd paid him for rent. After reviewing all the clues, I knocked on Dillon's door, and told him the news. "Ghosts didn't steal your saxophone. But I know who did."

original_metadata.reveal_text:
"Only Lenny had a key to my apartment," Dillon moaned sadly.
"But when could he steal it?" I pointed out. "He works with his father all day, and his father never gives him a break."
"That college student knew that my saxophone was valuable!"
"Yes, but Eric doesn't even know where you live," I pointed out. "He spoke to you over the phone, and he only had your phone number because he talked to Red."
"Red knows more about music than anyone," Dillon said, suspiciously. "He'd love to get his hands on a $20,000 saxophone."
"But Red gives music lessons from noon to five," I pointed out. "And anyways, he'd have no way to get into your locked apartment."
Dillon was puzzled. "But then who did?"
We walked out of his apartment and down the hallway to the building manager's room. As we knocked on the door, I finished my story.
"Red's music store had a customer last night," I said, "someone who 'owns a lot of buildings.' And the one other person who had a key to your apartment was your building manager."
"I bet he heard me practicing."
"I did more than that," a voice said, as the door swung open suddenly. "I recognized the songs."
The bald, short man, with the bristly moustache stared up at Dillon with a mischievous smile in his eyes. "You played like you were summoning up a legend, or a ghost."
"And maybe I did," said Dillon. "Meet Shorty Jenkins!"

"Red's music store had a customer last night," I said, "someone who 'owns a lot of buildings.' And the one other person who had a key to your apartment was your building manager."
"I bet he heard me practicing."
"I did more than that," a voice said, as the door swung open suddenly. "I recognized the songs."
The bald, short man, with the bristly moustache stared up at Dillon with a mischievous smile in his eyes. "You played like you were summoning up a legend, or a ghost."
"And maybe I did," said Dillon. "Meet Shorty Jenkins!"

detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1. Means / opportunity
   •  The saxophone vanished from a locked second-floor apartment.  
   •  Window was shut; broken fire-escape ladder makes an outside entry impossible.  
   •  Therefore the thief had to possess a key (or Dillon would have heard forced entry).

   •  People known to have keys  
        – Building manager (lives in the same hall).  
        – Lenny the grocery-boy (spare key for Friday deliveries).  
   •  Everybody else would need Dillon to let them in or would have to break in.

2. Motive
   •  Value: Eric tells us each horn is now worth c. $30,000.  
   •  Sentiment: only one person has an emotional as well as financial interest – the quartet’s old producer, Shorty Jenkins.  
   •  Shorty’s reputation already includes “using” the instruments of dead musicians to make money.

3. Alibis / schedules
   •  Lenny works all day beside his father, whose motto is literally “Work all day with no breaks ever.” No chance to slip away.  
   •  Red gives lessons noon-5 every day – precisely the period when Dillon states he was practising and then left the horn on its stand.  
   •  Eric never received Dillon’s address, only a phone number, and therefore could not locate the apartment that quickly.  
   •  The building manager’s whereabouts are never accounted for; tenants say they “never see him around.”

4. Physical clues
   •  Red recalls seeing an “oldest guy I’ve ever seen, five-foot-tall, bald, bristly moustache” in the store the previous night.  
   •  That description matches the vanished promoter, Shorty Jenkins.  
   •  The same description matches the apartment building manager.

5. Deduction
   •  Combine (i) exclusive possession of a pass-key, (ii) no outside access, (iii) absence of reliable alibi, and (iv) strong financial motive plus personal history with the horn.  
   •  The only person who satisfies every one of these conditions is the building manager, who turns out to be Shorty Jenkins himself.

Therefore the culprit is the building manager/Shorty Jenkins.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Lenny the grocery-boy, Eric the college student, “Red” the music-store owner, Building Manager / Shorty Jenkins
</SUSPECTS>

<CULPRIT>
Shorty Jenkins (posing as the apartment building manager)
</CULPRIT>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
The night before the theft, Shorty Jenkins—retired, bald, five-foot-tall and now the reclusive landlord of Dillon’s building—Visited Red’s music shop. There he overheard Eric discussing the immense present-day value of the quartet’s four historic saxophones and learned that Dillon still owned one.  

The next afternoon Shorty loitered in the hallway until he heard Dillon’s daily practise stop. Knowing the exact apartment layout (he owns the building) and possessing a master key, he unlocked Dillon’s door, lifted the antique saxophone from its stand, locked the door behind him and disappeared back into his own flat. No one questioned the familiar landlord walking the corridor, and there was no need for forced entry or the unusable fire escape.  

Shorty intended either to sell the horn privately to a collector or to reunite the instruments under his ownership for yet another profitable venture. His plan would have worked—until Dillon’s new detective connected the dots between the unknown landlord, Red’s description of the elderly visitor, and the historical name “Shorty Jenkins.”
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
•  Lenny: He was on duty bagging groceries the entire afternoon, under his father’s constant eye and “no-breaks-ever” rule. Even with a key he had no chance to leave the store, reach the apartment, and return unnoticed.  
•  Eric: He never possessed Dillon’s address, only a phone number obtained from Red. Without knowing the building, he could not have reached the locked apartment within the one-hour window.  
•  Red: At the time of the theft he was teaching lessons in his store, two blocks away, with students present who can verify it. He also lacks a key and thus had no means of entry.  

Only the landlord, secretly the famed promoter Shorty Jenkins, had key access, opportunity, motive, and the described physical appearance. That eliminates every other suspect.
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
